Fig. 1 Structure diagram and morphology of CoSe2@SnSe. (a) Schematic illustration of the preparation of CoSe2@SnSe; (b) FESEM images of CoSe2@SnSe composite; (c, d) HRTEM image of CoSe2@SnSe; (e) SAED images of CoSe2@SnSe; (f–i) TEM and corresponding elemental mapping of CoSe2@SnSe. Fig. 2 Structural characterizations of CoSe2@SnSe. (a) XRD patterns of CoSe2@SnSe composites at different etching times; (b) N2 adsorption and desorption isotherm profile of CoSe2@SnSe composites at different etching times; (c–e) the high-resolution spectra of Co, Sn, and Se in CoSe2@SnSe, CoSe2, and SnSe; (f) the 2D cross sectional view of the CoSe2@SnSe heterostructure (yellow: increased charge density, blue: decreased charge density). Fig. 3 Electrochemical performance of CoSe2@SnSe. (a) CV patterns of CoSe2@SnSe; (b) galvanostatic charge-discharge profiles of CoSe2@SnSe; (c) rate performance of CoSe2@SnSe; (d) EIS curves of the CoSe2@SnSe at different etching times; (e) long cycle stability of CoSe2@SnSe at different etching times; (f–j) AFM images of CoSe2@SnSe obtained at different etching times after 100 cycles; (k) performance radar plot of CoSe2@SnSe relative to reported TMS-based anodes. Fig. 4 The Na-ion storage mechanism of CoSe2@SnSe. (a) GCD curves of CoSe2@SnSe; (b) ex-situ XRD patterns of CoSe2@SnSe during the sodiation and desodiation processes; (c) ex-situ Raman curves of CoSe2@SnSe during discharge and charge processes; (d, e) HRTEM images of CoSe2@SnSe at the fully discharged stage and the fully charged stage; (f) DRT pattern of CoSe2@SnSe at different stages. Fig. 5 The analyses of sodium storage dynamics of CoSe2@SnSe. (a) CV patterns of CoSe2@SnSe at various scan rates from 0.1 to 0.6 mV s−1; (b) the plots of log i versus log v at specific peak rates; (c) the proportions of capacitive contribution at various rates; (d) CV patterns with capacitive contribution at 0.6 mV s−1; (e) the GITT patterns of CoSe2@SnSe; (f) the corresponding Na+ diffusion coefficient of CoSe2@SnSe. Fig. 6 Electrochemical performance of CoSe2@SnSe//Na3V2(PO4)3@C full battery. (a) Schematic illustration of the full cell; (b) GCD curves of the full battery at a current density of 0.5 A g−1; (c) rate performance of the full battery; (d) cycle stability of the full battery at a current density of 0.5 A g−1; (e) photograph of the LED array lighted by the full battery. Heterostructure of CoSe2@SnSe anode for high-rate performance sodium-ion battery Jiahe Li Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation a Kai Yang Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Project administration Formal analysis Data curation Conceptualization a ⁎ Dongyang Shu Formal analysis Data curation a Jian Tang Formal analysis Data curation a Yuhan Wu Formal analysis Data curation a Qinghua Deng Data curation a Hongying Zhuo Software Validation Writing – original draft b ⁎ Yan Su Writing – original draft Resources Project administration Data curation a ⁎ Nan Zhu Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Supervision Resources Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization a ⁎ a School of Chemistry, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, Liaoning, 116024 China School of Chemistry Dalian University of Technology Dalian Liaoning 116024 China School of Chemistry, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, Liaoning, China b State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian, Liaoning, 116023 China State Key Laboratory of Catalysis Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian Liaoning 116023 China State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The heterostructure of CoSe2@SnSe is precisely designed through a facile coprecipitation process followed by a selenization strategy. Benefiting from the internal electric field of CoSe2@SnSe, as-prepared anode materials exhibit excellent rate performance (409.5 mAh g−1 at 10 A g−1 and 577.2 mAh g−1 at 0.1 A g−1) and cycle stability (488.9 mAh g−1 after 900 cycles). Transition metal selenides (TMSs), as promising anode materials for sodium ion batteries (SIBs), still face sluggish Na+ diffusion kinetics and severe volume change, resulting in undesirable cycling stability and rate capability. Heterostructure construction is an effective method to improve sodium ion storage in TMSs. Herein, a hierarchical hollow heterostructure of CoSe2@SnSe is precisely designed through a facile coprecipitation process followed by a selenization strategy. The heterostructure constructed by CoSe2 and SnSe nanocrystals induces the formation of built-in electric fields and accelerates electron transfer and ion diffusion, thereby improving reaction kinetics significantly. When the as-prepared CoSe2@SnSe composites are employed as anode materials of SIBs, there exhibit ultra-fast electrochemical reaction kinetics and outstanding cycling stability with a high capacity retention of 488.9 mAh g−1 at a current density of 2.0 A g−1 after 900 cycles. In addition, there still shows an exceptional rate capability of 409.5 mAh g−1 at a high current density of 10 A g−1. This work provides an effective method for the rational designing of heterostructure anode materials for high-performance SIBs. Keywords Sodium-ion battery Transition metal selenides Heterostructure In-situ GEIS 1 Introduction Due to increasing concern about sustainable development and environmental problems, the development of new technology for energy storage has drawn tremendous attention. Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are the most commonly used energy storage source. Considering limited reserves and high costs of lithium, it is still imperative to explore alternative battery systems. Sodium has similar properties to lithium. Meanwhile, sodium is also much cheaper and more abundant than lithium. Thus, sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have been considered as a promising alternative to commercial LIBs [1–4]. Typically, SIBs are composed of cathode, electrolyte, and anode. However, the lack of suitable anode materials is a bottleneck for the development of SIBs. The anode materials of SIBs are generally divided into carbon-based materials, alloying compounds, and conventional materials [5,6]. Due to the low theoretical specific capacity of embedded materials and the poor stability of alloy materials, the synthesized materials have drawn attention in recent years [7–13]. As one of the synthesized materials, transition metal selenides (TMSs) have similar properties to transition metal sulfides [14]. Moreover, metal selenides have a lower band gap and higher electrode conductivity than metal sulfides, which undoubtedly improves the practical application potential of TMSs. However, TMSs also have the disadvantage of large volume changes that could cause damage to the electrode or even complete destruction of the structure. To fulfil the need of practical application, it is necessary to develop TMS electrode material with a stable structure to solve the volume change problem. It is well known that the heterointerface engineering is an efficient method to improve the chemical properties of electrodes. Heterostructure construction is considered to be an effective strategy to improve electrochemical reaction kinetics and enhance structural stability. Furthermore, the heterogeneous interface between different components can produce a local built-in electric field spontaneously. As a result, the electronic properties will be greatly improved through adjusting the interface reaction kinetics, which may lead to a lower ion diffusion barrier. For example, Zhang et al. reported Fe3Se4/ZnSe heterojunction bimetallic selenide as anode materials for SIBs. In-situ built heterostructures can shorten the ion diffusion pathway length and provide abundant active sites for sodium storage [15]. Gao et al. prepared Cu2Se/ZnSe embedded in carbon nanofibers (Cu2Se/ZnSe-CNFs) as the anode of SIBs for accelerating electron transport. This material delivered a high capacity of 310 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at 0.1 A g−1, which was attributed to the heterojunction between Cu2Se and ZnSe in composites [16]. Chen developed a yolk-shell Bi/Bi2S3 heterostructure encapsulated within S-doped carbon shells (TS-Bi/C) with a boosted discharge capacity of 462.3 mAh g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 [17]. Liang designed a pomegranate-inspired porous carbon shell wrapped heterogeneous SnSe/ZnSe composite (SnSe/ZnSe@C). This material showed excellent rate performance (177.8 mAh g−1 at 10.0 A g−1) [18]. Therefore, it is feasible to construct heterointerfaces to enhance the electrochemical properties of TMSs. In this work, CoSe2@SnSe material was fabricated through a facile hydrothermal method and employed as an anode of SIBs. Owing to the interaction of a certain internal electric field at the interface of the heterostructures of CoSe2@SnSe, the diffusion rate of sodium ions was accelerated, and the ion diffusion barrier was reduced during the cycle as well. CoSe2@SnSe nano heterostructure delivered high specific capacity (577.2 mAh g−1 at 0.1 A g−1) and excellent rate performance (reversible discharge capacity of 409.5 mAh g−1 at current density of 10 A g−1). This work provides an idea for the design of TMS electrodes with better performance for SIBs. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of CoSn(OH)6 Firstly, 2 mmol SnCl4 was dissolved in 10 mL ethanol to form solution A. 2 mmol CoCl2 and 2 mmol C6H5Na3O7 were dissolved in 70 mL deionized water and stirred for 30 min to form a uniform solution B. Solution A was slowly injected into solution B, followed by the addition of 10 mL NaOH solution (2 M). The above solution was stirred for 1 h and then stood for 1 h. The pink product was centrifuged, washed with deionized water and ethanol three times, and then vacuum dried overnight at 60 °C. 2.2 Synthesis of CoSn(OH)6@Co(OH)2 Firstly, 6 g NaOH was dissolved in 20 mL deionized water to form NaOH solution (solution C). Subsequently, 0.3 g of the as-prepared CoSn(OH)6 was dispersed in solution C, to etch the Sn in the composites to form CoSn(OH)6@Co(OH)2. To find the optimal etching time, the effect of different etching times was studied. 2.3 Synthesis of CoSe2@SnSe 2.5 mmol Se power was dissolved in 5 mL N2H4·H2O and stirred for 30 min to form a uniform solution D. Then, the as-prepared CoSn(OH)6@Co(OH)2 was dispersed in 20 mL deionized water to form solution E. Solutions D and E were mixed and transferred into 50 mL hydrothermal kettle and kept at 180 °C for 12 h. After being cooled down to room temperature, the black product was centrifuged, washed with deionized water and ethanol three times, and then vacuum dried overnight at 60 °C. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements The electrochemical performances for all as-prepared materials were evaluated through assembling CR2032 coin cells. The active materials, ketjen black, and polyvinylidene fluoride (at a mass ratio of 7:2:1) were dispersed in N-methyl pyrrolidone (NMP) solvent to obtain a slurry. The as-prepared slurry was coated onto Cu foils and dried at 110 °C for 12 h in a vacuum oven. Typically, the loading mass of the electrode was 1.0 mg cm−2. The half-battery was assembled in an Ar-filled glove box (O2, H2O < 0.01 ppm) with sodium metal as the counter electrode, glass fiber as a separator (GF/D, Whatman), and 1.0 mol L−1 sodium hexafluorophosphate (NaPF6) dissolved in 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME) as electrolyte. 2.5 Material characterizations The composition and crystal structure of as-prepared materials were determined by X-ray diffracton (XRD, Bruker D8 Advanced, Germany), using monochromatic Cu K α as a radiation source. The microstructure and morphology images were obtained using field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, NOVA Nano FESEM 450 FEI, US). The high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) was applied to test the hollow structure and selected-area electron diffraction (SAED). The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was acquired by an ESCALAB 250Xi XPS using Al K α (hν = 1486.6 eV) to determine the elemental valence and bonding of the materials. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Design, fabrication, and morphology characterization of CoSe2@SnSe The synthesis route of CoSe2@SnSe heterogeneous composites was schematically illustrated in Fig. 1 (a). Firstly, the CoSn(OH)6 precursor was fabricated through a simple coprecipitation method. Subsequently, NaOH solution was used to etch part of the tin precursor. Finally, CoSe2@SnSe composites were obtained via a facile hydrothermal method. The precursor CoSn(OH)6 exhibited a nanocube with a diameter of 500 nm (Fig. S1a). Then, etching removed Sn from CoSn(OH)6 precursor to form CoSn(OH)6@Co(OH)2 (Fig. S1b). The as-prepared CoSn(OH)6@Co(OH)2 and CoSe2@SnSe could also maintain the nanocube morphology from FESEM images (Fig. 1b). It is well known that tin (Sn) anode materials for SIBs demonstrate ultrahigh theoretical capacity. However, severe volume expansion poses significant challenges for practical applications. Partial etching of Sn enables retention of high-capacity characteristics while effectively mitigating the detrimental effects of substantial volume expansion on electrochemical performance. Meanwhile, the influence of etching duration was systematically investigated to optimize the properties of the material. As shown in Fig. S2, the prolonged etching time (18 and 24 h) leads to significant structural collapse in the prepared CoSe2@SnSe composite, adversely affecting cycling stability. Under short-duration etching time (0–6 h), CoSe2@SnSe maintains higher Sn content, leading to substantial volume variations during cycling that similarly compromise sodium-ion storage performance (Fig. S2 and Table S1). Thus, these results demonstrate that 12 h is the optimal etching time. In addition, the FESEM images of pure CoSe2 and SnSe were also captured (Fig. S3). As shown in Fig. 1(c), as-prepared CoSe2@SnSe exhibits a uniform hollow structure, which effectively alleviates the volume expansion effect during cycling and enhances cycling stability. The HRTEM images of CoSe2@SnSe show an obvious heterointerface between CoSe2 and SnSe, and the corresponding lattice spacings on two sides are in good accordance with CoSe2 and SnSe (Fig. 1d). The lattice fringes with interplane d-spacings of 0.237 and 0.216 nm agree with (211) and (002) crystal planes of CoSe2 and SnSe, respectively. The SAED image was explored to confirm the polycrystalline properties of CoSe2@SnSe (Fig. 1e). The inner and outer rings represent (211) and (023) planes of CoSe2, while the ring in the middle represents (002) planes of SnSe. Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping reveals that Co, Sn, and Se elements are uniformly distributed on the surface of the material (Fig. 1f–i). 3.2 Structural characterizations of CoSe2@SnSe The crystal structure of CoSn(OH)6 precursor was investigated by XRD. All peaks of precursor CoSn(OH)6 can be well indexed to the standard JCPDS card number (JCPDS No.74-0365) without impurity terms (Fig. S4). Along with the etching process, it could be observed the formation of Co(OH)2 peaks (Fig. S5). The diffraction peaks of the as-prepared CoSe2@SnSe are correlated well with CoSe2 (JCPDS 97-062-4998) and SnSe (JCPDS 04-009-2257) (Fig. 2 a). There is no excess hetero-peak observed, indicating complete conversion of CoSe2@SnSe. In addition, XRD patterns of pure CoSe2 and SnSe were also measured (Fig. S6). According to the N2 adsorption and desorption isotherm profile of CoSe2@SnSe composites at different etching times, the specific surface area of CoSe2@SnSe initially increased with etching time (Fig. 2b), achieving a maximum value of 31.61 m2 g−1 after 12 h, and then decreased with further increase of etching time. The etching process effectively removed surface impurities or amorphous phases, exposing more internal pores (such as mesopores or micropores), while increasing surface roughness. In contrast, longer etching times will lead to the collapse of pore walls, particle agglomeration, or partial closure of the pores caused by excessive etching. Furthermore, XPS was used to analyze the surface chemical composition and valence state (Fig. S7). The as-prepared composites were mainly comprised of Co, Sn, and Se elements. For high-resolution Co 2p XPS spectra of CoSe2@SnSe, two pairs of peaks at 781.2/797.4 eV and 778.6/793.5 eV can be assigned to Co2+ and Co3+, respectively, while other two peaks at 786.1 and 802.7 eV belong to doublet satellite (Sat.) peaks of Co 2p 3/2 and Co 2p 1/2, respectively (Fig. 2c). The high-resolution spectrum of Sn 3d was displayed in Fig. 2(d), and the characteristic peaks located at 486.9 and 495.3 eV could be ascribed to Sn 3d 5/2 and Sn 3d 3/2 of Sn2+ in SnSe, respectively. The peaks situated at 52.2, 53.2, and 57.8 eV of Se 3d XPS spectra could be assigned to Se 3d 5/2, Se 3d 3/2, and SeO x , respectively (Fig. 2e). Notably, the Co 2p spectra of CoSe2@SnSe composite exhibit a shift towards lower binding energies compared to pure CoSe2. The Sn 3d spectra of CoSe2@SnSe composite exhibit a shift towards higher binding energies compared to pure SnSe, attributed to the formed internal electric field at the CoSe2@SnSe heterointerface. This can also be proved through the two-dimensional (2D) cross-sectional view of CoSe2@SnSe heterostructure. Based on charge density difference diagram and associated 2D cross-sectional view of CoSe2@SnSe heterojunction interface, the yellow area (with increased charge density) is concentrated on the CoSe2 side, while the blue area (with decreased charge density) appears on the SnSe side (Fig. 2f). This suggests that electrons migrate from SnSe to CoSe2 and eventually accumulate on the CoSe2 side, thereby forming bipolar interface electric field (BIEF) extending from SnSe to CoSe2. 3.3 Electrochemical performance of CoSe2@SnSe The electrochemical performance of CoSe2@SnSe was further evaluated. Initial cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of the sample were displayed in Fig. 3 (a). During the first cathodic sweep of CoSe2@SnSe, a strong reduction peak was observed at 1.01 V. This peak can be attributed to the formation of Co/Na2Se. The oxidation peaks at 1.75 and 1.87 V indicate the transition of Co to CoSe2. In addition, there is an additional pair of redox peaks located at 1.63/1.51 V, corresponding to the sodium storage of SnSe. The initial three charge-discharge cycles of CoSe2@SnSe were shown in Fig. 3(b). The first discharge and charge capacities were 584 and 468 mAh g−1, with a high initial coulombic efficiency (CE) of around 80 %. The redox voltage plateaus corresponded well to CV curves. In the subsequent three cycles, the galvanostatic charge-discharge (GCD) curves of CoSe2@SnSe were nearly overlapped with a coulombic efficiency close to 100 %, exhibiting better cycle stability. CoSe2@SnSe etched for 12 h showed higher first-cycle CE compared with unetched CoSe2@SnSe, the CoSe2@SnSe materials that have been etched for 6, 18, or 24 h, as well as the pure CoSe2 and SnSe (Figs. S8 and S9). In addition, the rate performance of CoSe2@SnSe was examined at various current densities (0.1–10 A g−1) (Fig. 3c). CoSe2@SnSe delivered reversible capacities of 577.2, 507.6, 489.4, 480.5, 466.3, 437.8, 420.5, and 409.5 mAh g−1 at current density of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, 5, 8, and 10 A g−1, respectively (Fig. S10). Among various current densities, CoSe2@SnSe that has been etched for 12 h shows higher reversible capacities than other etched samples. Meanwhile, it is also higher than the reversible capacities of pure CoSe2 and SnSe (Fig. S9). Furthermore, the effect of etching time was investigated. CoSe2@SnSe that was etched for 12 h exhibited better electrochemical performance. Less than 12 h will make the reaction incomplete, while more than 12 h will lead to the structural collapse of the material and worse performance of the battery. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) also confirms the effect of the etching time of CoSe2@SnSe (Fig. 3d). 12 h etching exhibited a lower value of R ct, implying faster ionic/electronic transport kinetics. The long-term cycling properties of CoSe2@SnSe obtained at different etching times were studied at a high current density of 2.0 A g−1. Among them, the CoSe2@SnSe produced by etching for 12 h demonstrated the best initial specific discharge capacity (650.7 mAh g−1). After 900 cycles, the CoSe2@SnSe still maintained a high specific discharge capacity of 488.9 mAh g−1 (Fig. 3e). Furthermore, the morphologies before and after cycling were tested. It could be observed that the structure of the material was still well-maintained after cycling, thereby confirming excellent cycling stability (Fig. S11). At the loading of highly active substances (2–3.0 g), as-prepared composite materials still demonstrated excellent electrochemical performance (Fig. S12). To further confirm that CoSe2@SnSe etched for 12 h has more excellent electrochemical performance, atomic force microscope (AFM) was used to measure Young's modulus and roughness of the electrode sheet after 100 cycles (Fig. 3f–j). The Young's modulus of CoSe2@SnSe etched for 12 h after cycling was as high as 102 MPa, which was higher than that of unetched CoSe2@SnSe (32.4 MPa). The surface roughness (56.6 nm) of CoSe2@SnSe after being etched for 12 h was the lowest among all samples (unetched (151 nm), etched for 6 h (73.5 nm), 18 h (76.0 nm), and 24 h (92.3 nm)). CoSe2@SnSe with etching for 12 h performs a more stable and flatter solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) film during the cycling process, improving further cycling stability. To further confirm that the as-prepared material exhibits excellent electrochemical performance, we compared the cycling performance, rate capability, specific capacity, energy density, and power density of the reported TMS-based anode materials with those of the CoSe2@SnSe etched for 12 h [19–24]. From Fig. 3(k), it can be found that compared to the previously reported TMS-based anode materials, CoSe2@SnSe demonstrates stronger competitiveness and superior electrochemical performance, highlighting its significant potential for energy storage applications. The Na-ion storage mechanism of CoSe2@SnSe was investigated by ex-situ XRD (Fig. 4 a and b). The typical characteristic peaks of CoSe2@SnSe could be observed at the initial stage through ex-situ XRD patterns. It could be observed that the diffraction peaks of CoSe2 and SnSe gradually decreased, and the characteristic peaks of Na2Se located at 23° emerged during the discharge process, indicating that the sodium ions were inserted into the CoSe2@SnSe. When the discharge continued to around 0.5 V, SnSe was further transformed into the metallic phase Sn (Fig. S13). With the continued discharge to 0.2 V, the peaks of CoSe2 and SnSe completely disappeared, while the peak of Na2Se gradually increased, and the diffraction peaks of Na9Sn4 emerged. The diffraction peaks of Co may not be observed because of its low crystallinity. During the charging process, the peaks of Na2Se completely disappear at the fully charged state, while the characteristic peaks of CoSe2@SnSe reappear, revealing the reversibility of the sodium storage process. Ex-situ Raman test was employed to further understand the Na+ storage mechanism of CoSe2@SnSe (Fig. 4c). Obviously, the peaks located at 183 and 250 cm−1 could be attributed to CoSe2@SnSe. At the discharge stage, the Raman peaks of CoSe2@SnSe continuously decrease, while the Raman peaks of Na2Se appear and reach their maximum intensity at the fully discharged state. During the subsequent charging process, the corresponding Raman peaks of CoSe2@SnSe exhibit a gradual and reversible recovery. This further confirms the reversibility of CoSe2@SnSe during the charge and discharge cycle. The ex-situ HRTEM images also revealed the phase transition of CoSe2@SnSe. Fig. 4(d) displays the HRTEM image of CoSe2@SnSe at the fully discharged stage, revealing distinct lattice fringes that correspond to the (111) and (220) planes of the discharge product Na2Se, the (200) plane of Na9Sn4, and the (111) plane of metallic Co, respectively. After charging to 3.0 V, the lattice fringes of CoSe2 (0.262 nm) and SnSe (0.240 nm) reappear, demonstrating its excellent structural stability (Fig. 4e). Based on ex-situ XRD, ex-situ Raman, ex-situ HRTEM results, and previous references, the electrochemical process of CoSe2@SnSe could be explained by the following (1) CoS e 2 + 4 N a + + 4 e - ↔ Co + 2 N a 2 Se (2) SnSe + 2+ x N a + + 2+ x e - ↔ N a x Sn + N a 2 Se To further investigate the outstanding reversibility of the CoSe2@SnSe heterostructure during the sodium storage process. In-situ galvanostatic electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (GEIS) and distribution of relaxation times (DRT) were utilized to examine the changes in impedance at various stages of the charge and discharge processes (Fig. S14). It could be found that the charge transfer resistance (R ct) continues to grow with the voltage increases, which could be attributed to the formation of Na2Se during the electrochemical reaction process. This was consistent with the phase transition process revealed by ex-situ XRD (Fig. 4b). In order to more intuitively observe the variations of various impedances during the charging and discharging processes, the DRT technique was utilized to decouple the collected EIS data (Fig. 4f). It could be observed that the charge transfer resistance (R ct) and Na+ diffusion resistance (R d) increase rapidly during the charge process, reaching their maximum values at the fully charged state. This could be attributed to the continuous extraction of Na+ into the anode material, which was further transformed into CoSe2 and SnSe with worse conductivity and slower electron transfer. Upon further insertion of Na+, reversible changes in the values of R ct and R d could be observed, indicating that the electrochemical procedure of CoSe2@SnSe was completely reversible. 3.4 Electrochemical kinetic behaviors of CoSe2@SnSe To further understand the high rate and superior cycle stability performance of CoSe2@SnSe, the CV curves were collected at stepped scan rates from 0.1 to 0.6 mV s−1 (Fig. 5 a). It could be found that the shape of CV curves of CoSe2@SnSe were well-maintained with the increasing scan rate, indicating remarkable reversibility and weak electrochemical polarization. The peak current (i) and scan rate (v) comply with the following formula. (3) i = a v b The b value could be obtained by the following formula. (4) log( i )= log ( a )+ b log ( v ) where a represents a proportional coefficient and the value b is determined by the slope of log (i) and log (v); i and v are variable quantities. When the b value is close to 0.5, the capacity storage is limited by a diffusion-controlled process. b approaches 1.0, indicating that the electrochemical process was mainly controlled by the pseudocapacitive process. As shown in Fig. 5(b), the CV curves could be defined as two peaks, corresponding to fitting b-values of 0.84 and 0.74. It indicates that the electrochemical properties of CoSe2@SnSe were controlled by pseudocapacitive and diffusion-controlled processes. Furthermore, the contribution of pseudocapacitive and diffusion-controlled processes could be quantitatively calculated based on the following equation. (5) i ( v )= k 1 v + k 2 v 1/2 where k 1 v represents the pseudocapacitive process, and k 2 v 1/2 represents the diffusion contributions. The calculated pseudocapacitive contribution ratios for CoSe2@SnSe were 85 %, 89 %, 94 %, and 97 % at scan rates of 0.1, 0.2, 0.4, and 0.6 mV s−1, respectively (Fig. 5c). The contribution of pseudocapacitance (blue area) confirms the dominated pseudocapacitive contribution for CoSe2@SnSe (Fig. 5d). Benefiting from internal electric field between heterojunctions, the reaction kinetics during the sodium storage process is significantly accelerated. Galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) was used to further investigate the kinetics of sodium ions at various potentials (Fig. 5e), and D Na+ values can be determined using the following equation. (6) D N a + = 4 π τ m B V M M B S 2 Δ E S Δ E τ 2 where τ is the relaxation time (s), m B is the mass of the active materials, M B is the molar volume of the active materials, S is the contact area between the active materials and electrolyte, ΔE S denotes the potential variation in two consecutive relaxation periods, and ΔE τ stands for the potential variation between static state and equilibrium state. CoSe2@SnSe delivered a higher D Na+ (∼10−7.5–10−10 cm2 s−1), indicating much better reaction kinetics (Fig. 5f). The D Na+ of CoSe2@SnSe is also higher than that of CoSe2 (approximately 10−10.20–10−12.27 cm2 s−1) and SnSe (approximately 10−10.25–10−12.25 cm2 s−1), as a result of heterogeneous structures (Fig. S15). All observation results also confirm that the as-prepared anode materials have fast reaction kinetics and fast-charging ability. To evaluate the practical application prospects of CoSe2@SnSe, a commercial Na3V2(PO4)3@C (NVP@C) was employed as the cathode material (the XRD patterns and GCD curves of NVP are shown in Fig. S16), and the as-prepared CoSe2@SnSe served as the anode material to assemble a sodium-ion full battery (Fig. 6 a). The capacity of the full battery was calculated based on the active mass of the anode. Fig. 6(b) displays the GCD curves of CoSe2@SnSe//NVP@C full battery at different cycles. The full battery exhibited an initial discharge capacity of 352 mAh g−1 at a current density of 0.5 A g−1. The similar GCD curves show the good reversibility of CoSe2@SnSe//NVP@C full cell. The rate performance of the full battery is shown in Fig. 6(c). It could be observed that the full battery exhibited stable reversible capacities of 356, 353, 351, 333, 303, and 220 mAh g−1 at current densities of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, and 5.0 A g−1, respectively. In addition, the discharge capacity simultaneously returned to 365 mAh g−1, when the current density went back to 0.1 A g−1. Furthermore, the full battery delivered a stable specific capacity of 315 mAh g−1 with high-capacity retention of 88 % after 300 cycles at the current density of 0.5 A g−1, demonstrating the excellent reversibility of the assembled full battery (Fig. 6d). The calculated energy and power densities of CoSe2@SnSe//NVP full cell were tested. It was found that the CoSe2@SnSe//NVP full cell is better than the reported sodium ion full batteries (Fig. S17). Besides, the full battery could long-lastingly light up the light-emitting diode (LED) array (Fig. 6e), manifesting the promising application prospect of CoSe2@SnSe. 4 Conclusions In summary, CoSe2@SnSe was synthesized by a simple selenization process. This material showed a specific capacity of 488.9 mAh g−1 after 900 cycles at a current density of 2 A g−1. Due to the interaction of the internal electric field at the interface of the heterojunction structure, the diffusion speed of sodium ions can be accelerated, and the ion diffusion barrier can be reduced at the same time. As-prepared CoSe2@SnSe has a higher specific capacity and a smaller impedance, which would provide ideas for the design of novel TMS electrode materials with better performance for SIBs (Fig. S18). coredata.dc:description: Transition metal selenides (TMSs), as promising anode materials for sodium ion batteries (SIBs), still face sluggish Na+ diffusion kinetics and severe volume change, resulting in undesirable cycling stability and rate capability. Heterostructure construction is an effective method to improve sodium ion storage in TMSs. Herein, a hierarchical hollow heterostructure of CoSe2@SnSe is precisely designed through a facile coprecipitation process followed by a selenization strategy. The heterostructure constructed by CoSe2 and SnSe nanocrystals induces the formation of built-in electric fields and accelerates electron transfer and ion diffusion, thereby improving reaction kinetics significantly. When the as-prepared CoSe2@SnSe composites are employed as anode materials of SIBs, there exhibit ultra-fast electrochemical reaction kinetics and outstanding cycling stability with a high capacity retention of 488.9 mAh g−1 at a current density of 2.0 A g−1 after 900 cycles. In addition, there still shows an exceptional rate capability of 409.5 mAh g−1 at a high current density of 10 A g−1. This work provides an effective method for the rational designing of heterostructure anode materials for high-performance SIBs.

coredata.dc:title: Heterostructure of CoSe2@SnSe anode for high-rate performance sodium-ion battery
